segments.text: As things, as we talk and things occur, I'm certainly willing to move you into some kind of discretion or digression, excuse me.
My first question is, how did you develop your interest in oceanography?
What was your career leading to your service in Washington?
Well, my interest in oceanography came before I went to Washington.
I'd gone to school at New Mexico State University, Las Cruces, New Mexico, and majored in physics and minored in math, and I had
planned to do graduate work at Stanford University.
I had a fellowship all lined up right after my graduation.
And about a week before graduation, I drove up to Stanford to talk to the professor that I was going to be working with and got it all set.
And on the way back from Stanford to New Mexico, I picked up a copy of Life magazine.
and saw a two-page article on oceanography in Scripps.
So I decided Scripps was on the way back to New Mexico.
So I stopped into Scripps and met another physicist there.
Rusk was his name.
And he introduced me to Walter Monk, and I talked to him for the rest of the afternoon about what oceanography was all about and so on, and became interested in it.
I went back to New Mexico.
decided that I'd rather be in oceanography than in physics.
So I wrote a letter to Stanford and turned down my fellowship and wrote a letter to Walter Monk saying I'd be there in a week, see what he could do for me.
Now, I'd had three and a half years in the Navy immediately prior to that, where I was a quartermaster and worked on charts.
And so I had a little bit of feeling for some of the kinds of things that I thought oceanography involved.
And I lived near the oceans all my life in Southern California.
So it was kind of a natural, I think, to go into it.
Well, like I said, about a week later, I drove out to Scripps.
And I went in to see Walter Monk and asked him how I went about either getting a job or getting enrolled.
I wanted to do some graduate work.
And at that same day, Teddy Bullard
Sir Edward Bullard from England arrived, and he needed a graduate student to work for him, so they paired the two of us off, and we spent all that summer, that was in 1949, working on heat flow work.
This was the first heat flow work that had been done at sea.
A little bit had been done by Hans Pedersen and the Albatross expedition, but he hadn't made any successful measurements, so
We started in on that.
I spent a summer with Teddy, which was an absolute delightful summer.
Neither of us knew much about La Jolla or Scripps at the time.
But it was a great summer.
Got me started in oceanography.
Then I went on and got my master's degree there in 1951 and worked for a number of people at Scripps.
Primarily, John Isaacs, I would say, was the main person after working on my thesis material.
But I worked while I was there closely with Roger Revell, who was director.
He was my most immediate thesis advisor, so I worked as close to him as anybody.
Actually, Roger was an interesting person because he would come in in the morning and he'd run scripts during the daytime.
He was just director at that time.
In the evening, I'd go over to his house about 8 o'clock every night, and we'd work about 3 o'clock in the morning on science.
Almost every night.
Much to the consternation of Ellen, his wife, objected to us spoiling all the evenings doing that.
But in a way, I kind of grew up with one of their families.
I spent several years in this kind of pattern, so I got to know Roger and his family very well.
I left...
scripts in 1955 to go to the Office of Naval Research.
I'd like to interject a couple questions here.
Did you work on heat flow from 49 to 55?
That's right.
And you worked with Isaacs on heat flow too?
No, I worked with John Isaacs on another program.
The heat flow was the basis of my thesis for my PhD.
And I worked primarily with Roger Revelle on that.
A few other people that I don't recall their names right now.
A physicist who is from San Diego State was working there, worked with me.
And every once in a while, projects would come up.
And being a graduate student, you had cheap labor there, so I'd get off on these.
And some of these were measuring waves at the bomb tests at Bikini.
Now, I want you to say a few words about that.
Let me back off just one step from that.
I guess it was in 1951 that we went out on a mid-pack cruise, which was the first Scripps cruise after the war that went from San Diego to Hawaii and back.
And I did heat flow work on that.
The first heat flow work was accomplished on that.
That was followed by their Capricorn expedition
that went out from San Diego to the Marshall Islands and then down to Fiji, Samoa, Tahiti, and so on and back.
And we got a lot of heat glomations on that.
And those two cruises formed the main basis for my thesis work.
There were a few other shorter cruises afterwards, but that was the main part of it.
51, I believe it was, I went out to the bomb tests.
I participated in, oh, three or four of these different bomb tests, which I designed some instruments that could be set underwater.
It was essentially a very simple thing.
It was a pan inverted with a screen on the bottom and a basketball bladder inside.
It would be half filled with air, then ran a tube up to the surface and to a recorder in the boat.
And it required scuba diving to set these.
They were set in about 60 feet of water.
I can remember the first day I went scuba diving, I was out in bikini with Bill Bascom, who was quite an accomplished scuba diver at the time.
And he said, put the lung on.
We put it on.
We walked into the surf.
And he said, if you get water in it, just turn up your head and blow on it and blow it out.
And he said, try it once.
And I tried it once.
And then we took off.
There we were.
Went right down to 60 feet.
That's the only lesson I had in scuba diving.
Quite different than it is today on that.
But we would go out there.
And Phoenix Jennings was out there on part of this.
Set these instruments.
And I can remember the first H-bomb test.
I've forgotten exactly when that was.
We were out there.
and had instruments set on it.
The test went off, and it went about five times larger than they expected.
And it radiated all the area in our campground where we had our tents and clothes and equipment.
But fortunately, everything that we had was self-contained in a trailer.
So we moved this aboard a ship, and it wasn't contaminated inside.
We'd lost all our clothes.
All I had with me was a bathing suit and toothbrush that I'd taken out in the carrier.
So we were able to keep in business on that, but it wiped almost everybody in the test scene out of business for about a month.
So we spent the month out there tuning up the instruments and so on until the next series of tests started.
I think we were out there three months or so on that test.
And the plan of the day would be to go out and go around all the instruments, set them, make sure they were all set to record.
Then we were usually the last person to leave the lagoon

we needed to set our instruments just sort of before the test, so we'd take off in the helicopter, fly out to the aircraft carrier, watch the blast go off from the aircraft carrier, and then we'd take a helicopter and we'd be back in, and they'd drop us off in a boat, and we'd go around and pick all our records up, and we were the first ones back in the scene afterwards, so we were kind of the last to leave and the first back after all these tests, and they were really interesting tests, and we
a good set of measurements on what the waves were like that were generated from these tests.
Were you working with Walter Munk then on the wave measurements?
No, that was primarily with John Isaacson.
John was working on those and John went out on several of those tests himself.
Let's see.
Well, it was after those series of tests and
Gordon Lill came back to visit me at Scripps, and he and John Adkins from ONR tried to talk me into coming back to Washington.
It was right at the beginning of the IGY getting organized for it, which was in 1957, and this was in 1955.
And they wanted me to help back there, and I felt like I was getting in a rut at Scripps.
I was spending more and more of my time
working on these programs and less and less trying to finish up my thesis.
So I felt that the only way I'd really get myself to get right down to it was to get away from that atmosphere.
So I went to Washington.
And then it took me four years after going to Washington before I finished up PhD.
It was working evenings and weekends.
It was a long, drawn out thing, which I finally managed to get in 1959.
When I first went to work for ONR, Gordon Little was my boss there.
And we were in the geophysics branch.
We had three sections in there.
There was a meteorology section, earth physics section, and an oceanography section.
And I came back to head the oceanography section.
Dick Better was actually working in the oceanography section at that time.
Gordon was head of the branch.
And it was a nice, good little group.
It was one of the most interesting places I've ever worked.
Gordon is a great guy to work for.
And it was a can-do place.
The whole atmosphere around there was if somebody had a good idea, we'd find a way to do it.
And that not only went with the scientific part of the group, but the contracting part of ORNR was that way.
And this is really in contrast to almost any agency that exists in the federal government now, even NSF.
If something comes up, the questions are, what are the problems about it?
All the reasons why you can't do it instead of just the other way around.
And I think it made ONR really a great place to do things from.
A lot of good science was supported just because of this attitude that existed there.
Well, I worked for ONR for 10 years.
I started as head of the oceanography group and then worked up to being head of the geophysics branch when I left.
Gordon had left to go to Lockheed, somewhere along there, and I took over his job.
I don't know whether there's anything about that particular era that's...
Yes, I have several questions about ONR I'd like to ask.
You were at ONR when the Mansfield Amendment came through.
That's correct.
When was the date of that?
I think it was 61.
61 is when the Mansfield Amendment came through.
I was there.
Some people have maintained that the Mansfield Amendment almost ends the productivity of ONR vis-a-vis oceanography.
By the time it becomes more and more
narrowly construed on what kind of age you go to oceanography, oceanography suffers.
Would you agree with that?
No, I wouldn't agree with it.
I think the timing is approaching being right.
That ONR was becoming less and less a factor in not only oceanography, but all science about that stage.
Because oceanography was getting close to being 20 years old or something.
NSF had
been going, I've forgotten when NSF was started, but it was in the 50s sometime.
It started out with a small budget, but it was growing, and it was obviously the place that should be supporting science for science's sake on a broad basis.
There was no doubt that ONR was going to have to restrict its interests somewhat.
Now, when I was there, we were

keenly aware of this situation, and I urged the Chief of Naval Research that it ought to support more things like oceanography and worry less about mathematics, psychology, nuclear physics, and so on.
And indeed, there was a shift toward that during this time.
And the Chief of Naval Research that was Admiral Layden at that time was very sympathetic to that point of view.
I think one could justify supporting oceanography, even in its broadest sense, vis-a-vis supporting the whole broad science.
But now, the Mansfield Amendment came into effect in 61.
And as I recall, it was only in effect for one year.
But it had a lasting effect that's there even now, because a lot of the agencies say we've got to be mission-oriented, particularly the Navy on this.
Guys like Proxmire look at things and gives his Golden Fleece Award if they're too far off the beam on these kind of things.
I think this has pervaded the whole business and has hung on for a long time.
But I think it was probably a timely thing that if you hadn't had a Mansfield Amendment, you probably would be running into the same situation in any case.
I think by this stage of the game that O&R would be phasing out a lot of things.

I would have hoped that they could have stayed strong in oceanography, that it could have been one of their major fields, and that it might support roughly a third of the work that's going on in the business now.
NSF should be supporting about a third, the Navy about a third, and NOAA from a civilian agency, the civilian side, supporting about a third.
That kind of balance, it seems to me, makes more sense.
And I think that's the way it's headed.
The military has just faded off into the business, and that's as it should.
It's built way up.
during World War II, and it's phased down to a level, but it's gradually phasing down.
So I think it shouldn't play as much of a role as it did at one time.
I'm not going to name their names, of course, but several of your colleagues in federal agencies at the time when you guys were so active there maintained that this was the most creative time
of the federal bureaucracy, that they feel as if there were more excitement in your agency, in other agencies, NNSL, about this time than ever before.
And somehow I have inferred or have at least drawn the conclusion that it's not like that anymore.
Now, what I'd like you to comment on is both phases.
Do you think this is true?
And if it's not like that anymore, why?
Yes, I think it was true.
I think being in Washington was fun at that time.
I don't think it's that way anymore.
Those are the exact phrases they all use.
It was once fun, it's no longer fun.
It's a chore now.
You're justifying everything.
At that time, you could build programs.
It was very freewheeling.
And I think one of the reasons for this is that science was on a very steep part of the curve going up at that time.
And there was more money each year.

more money significantly above inflation on it so that you're on an expanding curve and you could do creative things on that now the budgets have leveled off and are approaching inflation or maybe going up slightly with respect to it but not much and there's more competition for every dollar I think in part this is the reason for this is that science has just become very expensive and you know
you can't do everything in science anymore.
There's a lot of things that people can do if you had the money, but there just isn't enough money to do.
At that time, I think the situation was the other way around.
The technology was such that you could put your money into the new kinds of technology, and you could afford to support all of the new technology at that stage of the game.
And that made it an exciting time to be there.
And I think this is just gone, and it won't be recovered again, just by the nature of the beast.
Now things are so sophisticated that even in oceanography we can't do.
We could spend all the money that's budgeted for science if we really wanted to, and you just can't afford to put priorities on things like that.
OK. Now others, in this case not your colleagues, but people contemporaneous with you, maintain that one of the reasons why the ONR was so innovative then
was that the tendency towards block funding, the idea to invest good ideas, and they maintain that now, with the concept of peer review and careful justification, that that can't happen anymore.
What are your feelings about peer review and careful justification of your project?
Well, again, I suspect this is related more to the situation that exists
then and now.
And when I was in ONR, we didn't have peer review.
We had a group of people that looked at programs.
We made judgment.
We tend to bet on people, good people we supported, and gave them a lot of leeway to do what they wanted.
And I think we had good results on that.
We weren't forced to justify our money so much, and therefore we didn't, in turn,
pass this on to the people that we were giving money, as long as good results were coming in.

I think the way we used to play the game in ONR is that we considered we'd put something like 60 or 70 percent of our money on what we called blue chip research, just first-rate people in the business.
We'd just give them the money they needed and let them do what they wanted.
And we used to take a smaller percentage of it and
play the big risks.
And they were kind of the fun things to play.
Some of them panned out, and some of them didn't.
And that's a very fine line between what's a blue chip and what's a big risk on it.
It's no straight line, but it gradates into it.
I think as money has become short,

And even when I left the Navy, it was getting to be more and more of a job of justifying to DDR&E and other places your budgets, that you had to become more critical of where you were spending the money, get these people to write more specific proposals.
And then you had to have some way to review these.
And I think the peer system, I don't know that it was ever
initiated as such, but I think it just grew, particularly in NSF.
I think even in the early days of NSF, there was a good possibility that the program managers could make decisions on what they wanted to support and so forth.
And this has gradually disappeared over the time, where for one reason or another, including
congressional pressure that they're forced to justify decisions they make on these, and they need to send it out for review, get written reviews, and so on.
It's more of a protective mechanism than an innovative mechanism of doing research.
It's to make sure that if they get in trouble, they can show that they're right.
Again, it's just the opposite kind of attitude that I think existed in that time, where
There was an attitude to go out and do.
If there was a good idea, you'd go out and do it.
I can give you an example of an interesting thing that happened in O&R when Gordon and I were there, which shows you the flexibility we had.
Bill Van Dorn from...
This was right after Sputnik went off.
Bill Van Dorn from Scripps came in with an idea of...
putting something into orbit.

And his idea was to essentially bore a hole in the ground and put about three or four atomic bombs on it in a projectile and fire them off one after the other as it went off to fire this fairly heavy payload into orbit.
Well, it was an interesting thing at the time.
And Rockefeller was in town.
And we got Bill Baskin.
I remember Bill Bascom got Rockefeller involved in it.
He and Rockefeller came over to my house one evening and we discussed this whole thing.
We decided we ought to classify it at that time because it was an interesting idea.
As a result of this, we gave a physicist at, well I'm not sure where it was, I think it was the University of Illinois, $50,000 to make a feasibility study.
to see whether this made any sense to put something in orbit this way, just looking at the physics of it.

Here's something that has no relation to oceanography or hardly any relation to the earth sciences or atmospheric sciences, yet we could spend money that way and what we thought was a good idea and follow it through.
In actuality, as a result of this, it was a great long classified study that
which I don't know how it ever came out, but went into the whole program looking at it.
But we had flexibility.
You could do things like that, and nobody complained as long as you thought it was a good idea and could sell it that way.
I feel that that's the kind of flexibility and attitude that you're not able to have.
I'm not sure that a lot of people wouldn't like to have it in Washington.
Now I
I think the climate has changed there where it's just not possible to do that.
I only have one more comment along that line.
Some people maintain that to have that sort of flexibility, not only do you need to return back to the earlier days of ONR, but possibly what you ought to do is make amends

manager and then responsible for the decisions and not responsible for not responsible to the peer reviews that is what they're saying is that now the peer reviews have become the managers rather than sort of the advisory committee to a competent manager if that's good enough put for it yes it is and i agree completely with it and i think this is still the way onr is run that is the people you know in onr that are

supporting oceanography they make the decisions and they have to stand on it whether it's good decisions or bad decisions bad decision their funding is going to get cut off as is everybody's that gets funded for them and they may call on people for advice but they're not they're no fall guy for them and i agree that the the peer review system has gotten to be a way of shedding the responsibility and and really
trying to play things as safe as possible, which I don't think you can do in research.
I think it's tending in the wrong direction there.
Now, what it takes, though, if you're going to have a group of people in NSF that's supporting programs and they're going to have to live or die by it, it takes good people there.
And I think
That's probably another thing that has changed over the years.
When I was in ONR, ONR had some of the top scientists in the country working there.
I mean, absolutely first-rate people that have become college presidents and so on since they left there.
They were first-rate people.
They put their time in and they made decisions on this.
NSF has had good people and does have good people, but

I think, by and large, what NSF has tended to do is bring in young people because of the difficulty of getting people to come to Washington, young, immature people that are not capable of making decisions on this, and then they have to fall back on the peer review system in order to make good judgment.
They're just not capable of doing it themselves.
And I think this is important because you have a lot of very young people that haven't been around
Well, as a matter of fact, you've anticipated a question I have.
How do you explain that, let me draw a scenario for you.
Roger Revelle, ONR, split in NSL, yourself, Finn and Jennings, Isaac's going back, and how do you explain the ending of that?
Because that no longer happens.
When somebody goes to the ONR desk now, it's almost as if they're looking for a sabbatical.
Yeah.
Well,
I don't know how you explain that now.
Even in the early days of NSF, I think a lot of scientists went there and spent two or three years there as just sort of part of their careers to do that.
I don't detect that so much now.
I think what you tend to get are people that stay in Washington all the time.
that never leave, and then you have an influx of people that come in for a very short period of time, like a year on this.
But I think ONR had, I don't know what the mean life of people was during that, during ONR's early stages, but I would suspect it was more like five years or something of that order.
And now I think, well, the mean life of all,
all people in NSF may be the same, but I think it breaks down into two groups.
You have one group of people that comes in for about a year, and then you have another group of people that never leaves.
If I look at the section of NSF I know best, most people have been there ten years or more, I guess.
Well, they haven't been in NSF necessarily, but they've been in the government one way or another for a very long period of time.
Now, maybe that isn't bad.
I don't know.
I tend to feel that you sort of get stale in any job after a period of time.
It probably makes sense to move on.
Those of us who are not administrators maintain five years.
I wouldn't say more like seven, but...
that order of time, you know, the government is a tough place to work if you come in from the outside and don't know anything about it.
And it really takes something like two years to get up to speed so you can really know how to do things in the government.
And then you can be innovative for maybe five years after that.
Then you start going over the same ground again.
And I suspect that's pretty much true in any job.
I would think five to seven years is...
is a time people should move on, particularly in administrative spots.
I'm saying that knowing that I've been in this spot 12 years now.
